mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="f(u_{i})=2i-1,\ \ \ \ i=1,2,...,n,\ \ u_{i}\in X_{n}" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>u</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>i</mi></mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="22.5pt">,</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="12.5pt">,</mo><mrow><msub><mi>u</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>∈</mo><msub><mi>X</mi><mi>n</mi></msub></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="f(v_{j})=2j,\ \ \ \ \ j=1,2,...,n,\ \ v_{j}\in Y_{n}" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>j</mi></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="27.5pt">,</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="12.5pt">,</mo><mrow><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mo>∈</mo><msub><mi>Y</mi><mi>n</mi></msub></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
Note that there  is no edge $u_iu_{i+1} \in X_n$ and $v_jv_{j+1}\in Y_n$, where $i,j=1,2,...,n$.\\
It is easy to see that $f$ is a bijection from the union of the vertex set and edge set of $K_{n,n}$ to the set $\{1,2,...,n(2+n)\}$.\\ \
\\
For the edge-weight of the edge $u_iv_j,\ \ i,j=1,2,...,n$ under the labeling $f$, we have
\begin{eqnarray*}

  wt_f(u_iv_j) &=& f(u_i)+f(u_iv_j)+f(v_j) \\
   &=& 2i-1+n(2+j)-(i-1)+2j \\
   &=& n(2+j)-2j-i+1
\end{eqnarray*}



The weights of all edges $u_iv_j\in E(K_{n,n})$ are different under the labeling $f$ which implies that the labeling $f$ is EAT.\\ \
\\
We have to check also that the vertex-weight are different. For the vertex $u_i, \ \ i=1,2,...,n$, we have
\begin{eqnarray*}

 wt_f(u_i) &=& f(u_i)+\sum^n_{j=1}f(u_iv_j), \ \ i=1,2,...,n \\
   &=& 2i-1+\sum^n_{j=1}n(2+j)-(1-i) \\
  &=& i(2-n)+\frac{n}{2}(n^2+5n+2)-1
\end{eqnarray*}



Thus $wt_f(u_{i+1})=wt_f(u_i)-n+2$ which implies that $wt_f(u_i)>wt_f(u_{i+1})$, for $i=1,2,...,n-1$ (since $n>3$). Therefore the weights of vertex $u_i$ are all distinct.\\ \
\\
For the vertex $v_j \ \ j=1,2,...,n$, we get
\begin{eqnarray*}

  wt_f(v_j) &=& f(v_j)+\sum^n_{i=1}f(u_iv_j), \ \ \ j=1,2,...,n \\
   &=& 2j+\sum^n_{i=1}n(2+j)-(i-1) \\
   &=&  j(2+n^2)+\frac{n}{2}(1+3n)
\end{eqnarray*}



As $K_{n,n}$ is a regular graph, we have $deg(u_i)=deg(v_j)=n,\ \ \ i,j=1,2,...,n$.\\ \
\\
Thus
 \begin{eqnarray*}
 
 wt_f(v_j) &=& j(2+n^2)+\frac{n}{2}(1+3n) \\
   &=& wt_f(v_{j+1})-n^2-2
 \end{eqnarray*}
 

Therefore $wt_f(v_j)<wt_f(v_{j+1})$, for $j=1,2,...,n-1$ and the weights of vertex $v_j,\ \ j=1,2,...,n$ are all distinct.\\ \
\\
As $wt_f(u_i)$ and $wt_f(v_j)$  are all different, this means that the labeling $f$ is VAT.\\
Also, since $wt_f(v_j)<wt_f(v_{j+1})$ where $f(v_j)<f(v_{j+1})$ and \ \  $wt_f(u_i)\nless wt_f(u_{i+1})$, for $f(u_i)<f(u_i+1)$, where $i,j=i,2,...,n-1$, this means that the graph $K_{n,n}$ is a weak ordered graph. \\
\\
Hence, since the labeling  $f$ is simultaneously EAT and VAT, the graph $K_{n,n}$ is a weak ordered super TAT graph.
\end{proof}

Next, we show that complete bipartite graph with different number of vertices in each partite set is a TAT graph.

\begin{theorem}
Let $n,m$ be positive integers such that $n,m\geq 3$, then the graph $K_{n,m}$ is a weak ordered super TAT  graph.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
Partition the graph $K_{n,m}$ into two sets $X_n$ and $Y_m$. Denotes the vertices of $X_n$ and $Y_m$ by the symbols $u_i$ and $v_j$ respectively, where $i=1,2,...,n$ and $j=1,2,...,m$. The number of vertices $p$ in $K_{n,m}$ is $n+m$ and the number of edges $q$ is $nm$. The edge set of $K_{n,m}$ is $u_iv_j$, where $1\leq i\leq n$ and $1\leq j\leq m$. We split the proof into the following three cases.\\
\\
Case $1$: $n$ even and $m$ a positive integer.\\
Consider the labeling $f:V(K_{n,m})\cup E(K_{n,m})\rightarrow \{1,2,...,p+q\}$ defined as

prevtext:
Note that there  is no edge $u_iu_{i+1} \in X_n$ and $v_jv_{j+1}\in Y_n$, where $i,j=1,2,...,n$.\\
It is easy to see that $f$ is a bijection from the union of the vertex set and edge set of $K_{n,n}$ to the set $\{1,2,...,n(2+n)\}$.\\ \
\\
For the edge-weight of the edge $u_iv_j,\ \ i,j=1,2,...,n$ under the labeling $f$, we have
\begin{eqnarray*}

  wt_f(u_iv_j) &=& f(u_i)+f(u_iv_j)+f(v_j) \\
   &=& 2i-1+n(2+j)-(i-1)+2j \\
   &=& n(2+j)-2j-i+1
\end{eqnarray*}



The weights of all edges $u_iv_j\in E(K_{n,n})$ are different under the labeling $f$ which implies that the labeling $f$ is EAT.\\ \
\\
We have to check also that the vertex-weight are different. For the vertex $u_i, \ \ i=1,2,...,n$, we have
\begin{eqnarray*}

 wt_f(u_i) &=& f(u_i)+\sum^n_{j=1}f(u_iv_j), \ \ i=1,2,...,n \\
   &=& 2i-1+\sum^n_{j=1}n(2+j)-(1-i) \\
  &=& i(2-n)+\frac{n}{2}(n^2+5n+2)-1
\end{eqnarray*}



Thus $wt_f(u_{i+1})=wt_f(u_i)-n+2$ which implies that $wt_f(u_i)>wt_f(u_{i+1})$, for $i=1,2,...,n-1$ (since $n>3$). Therefore the weights of vertex $u_i$ are all distinct.\\ \
\\
For the vertex $v_j \ \ j=1,2,...,n$, we get
\begin{eqnarray*}

  wt_f(v_j) &=& f(v_j)+\sum^n_{i=1}f(u_iv_j), \ \ \ j=1,2,...,n \\
   &=& 2j+\sum^n_{i=1}n(2+j)-(i-1) \\
   &=&  j(2+n^2)+\frac{n}{2}(1+3n)
\end{eqnarray*}



As $K_{n,n}$ is a regular graph, we have $deg(u_i)=deg(v_j)=n,\ \ \ i,j=1,2,...,n$.\\ \
\\
Thus
 \begin{eqnarray*}
 
 wt_f(v_j) &=& j(2+n^2)+\frac{n}{2}(1+3n) \\
   &=& wt_f(v_{j+1})-n^2-2
 \end{eqnarray*}
 

Therefore $wt_f(v_j)<wt_f(v_{j+1})$, for $j=1,2,...,n-1$ and the weights of vertex $v_j,\ \ j=1,2,...,n$ are all distinct.\\ \
\\
As $wt_f(u_i)$ and $wt_f(v_j)$  are all different, this means that the labeling $f$ is VAT.\\
Also, since $wt_f(v_j)<wt_f(v_{j+1})$ where $f(v_j)<f(v_{j+1})$ and \ \  $wt_f(u_i)\nless wt_f(u_{i+1})$, for $f(u_i)<f(u_i+1)$, where $i,j=i,2,...,n-1$, this means that the graph $K_{n,n}$ is a weak ordered graph. \\
\\
Hence, since the labeling  $f$ is simultaneously EAT and VAT, the graph $K_{n,n}$ is a weak ordered super TAT graph.
\end{proof}

Next, we show that complete bipartite graph with different number of vertices in each partite set is a TAT graph.

\begin{theorem}
Let $n,m$ be positive integers such that $n,m\geq 3$, then the graph $K_{n,m}$ is a weak ordered super TAT  graph.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
Partition the graph $K_{n,m}$ into two sets $X_n$ and $Y_m$. Denotes the vertices of $X_n$ and $Y_m$ by the symbols $u_i$ and $v_j$ respectively, where $i=1,2,...,n$ and $j=1,2,...,m$. The number of vertices $p$ in $K_{n,m}$ is $n+m$ and the number of edges $q$ is $nm$. The edge set of $K_{n,m}$ is $u_iv_j$, where $1\leq i\leq n$ and $1\leq j\leq m$. We split the proof into the following three cases.\\
\\
Case $1$: $n$ even and $m$ a positive integer.\\
Consider the labeling $f:V(K_{n,m})\cup E(K_{n,m})\rightarrow \{1,2,...,p+q\}$ defined as
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex4.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="f(u_{i})=i,\ \ \ 1\leq i\leq n,\ \ \ u_{i}\in X_{n}" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>u</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>i</mi></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><mn>   1</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>i</mi><mo>≤</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="17.5pt">,</mo><mrow><msub><mi>u</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>∈</mo><msub><mi>X</mi><mi>n</mi></msub></mrow></mrow></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex5.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="f(v_{j})=n+j,\ \ \ 1\leq j\leq m,\ \ \ v_{j}\in Y_{m}" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>j</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><mn>   1</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>j</mi><mo>≤</mo><mi>m</mi></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="17.5pt">,</mo><mrow><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mo>∈</mo><msub><mi>Y</mi><mi>m</mi></msub></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
The labeling $f$ is a bijection from the vertex set to the set $\{1,2,...,n+m\}$ which shows that $K_{n,m}$ is super. Also, labeling $f$ is a bijection from the union of the vertex set and the edge set of $K_{n,m}$ to the set $\{1,2,...,n(1+m)+m\}$.\\
 \\
 The edge-weight of the edge $u_iv_j,\ \ 1\leq i\leq n, \ \ \ 1\leq j\leq m$ is \begin{eqnarray*}
    
      wt_f(u_iv_j) &=& f(u_i)+f(u_iv_j)+f(v_j) \\
       &=& i+nj+m+i+n+j \\
       &=& 2i+j(1+n)+n+m
    \end{eqnarray*}
 
 
 
 The weights of all the edges are different under the labeling $f$ which means that the labeling $f$ is EAT.\\ \
 \\
 Moreover, for the vertex $u_i\in X_n$, we obtain the vertex weights as follows:
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 \begin{eqnarray*}
 
   wt_f(u_i)& = & f(u_i)+\sum_{j=1}^mf(u_iv_j), \ \ \ 1\leq i\leq n \\
    &=& i+\sum_{j=1}^mnj+m+i  \\
    &=& i(1+m)+\frac{m}{2}(m(n+2)+n) \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ (2.1)
 \end{eqnarray*}
 For the vertex $v_j\in Y_m$, we obtain the vertex-weight
 \begin{eqnarray*}
 
    wt_f(v_j) &=& f(v_j)+\sum_{i=1}^nf(u_iv_j), \ \ \ \ \ 1\leq j\leq m \\
    &=& n+j+\sum_{i=1}^nnj+m+i \\
    &=& j(1+n^2)+\frac{n}{2}(2m+n+3) \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ (2.2)
 \end{eqnarray*}
 
 
 

 The weights of the vertices are distinct under the labeling $f$ which implies that the labeling $f$ is VAT.\\ \
 \\
 Also, from equation (2.1), $wt_f(u_i)<wt_f(u_{i+1})$ whenever $f(u_i)<f(u_{i+1})$ and from equation (2.2), $wt_f(v_j)<wt_f(v_{j+1})$ whenever $f(v_j)<f(v_{j+1})$. This implies that $K_{n,m}$ is a weak ordered graph.\\ \
 \\
 Finally, since the graph $K_{n,m}$ admits the labeling $f$ that is simultaneously EAT and VAT, then $K_{n,m}$ is a TAT graph.\\ \
\\
 Case $2$: $n$ odd and $m$ even.\\
 By interchanging the partition set $X_n$ with $Y_m$ and $Y_m$ with $X_n$ in case $1$ above gives the result.\\ \
\\
 Case $3$: $n,m$ odd.\\
 Consider the labeling $f:K_{n,m}\rightarrow \{1,2,...,p+q\}$ defined as follows:
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex6.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="f(u_{i}v_{j})=nj+m+i,\ \ \ 1\leq j\leq m,1\leq i\leq n." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msub><mi>u</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>j</mi></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>j</mi></mrow><mo>+</mo><mi>m</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>i</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><mn>   1</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>j</mi><mo>≤</mo><mi>m</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>i</mi><mo>≤</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

The labeling $f$ is a bijection from the vertex set to the set $\{1,2,...,n+m\}$ which shows that $K_{n,m}$ is super. Also, labeling $f$ is a bijection from the union of the vertex set and the edge set of $K_{n,m}$ to the set $\{1,2,...,n(1+m)+m\}$.\\
 \\
 The edge-weight of the edge $u_iv_j,\ \ 1\leq i\leq n, \ \ \ 1\leq j\leq m$ is \begin{eqnarray*}
    
      wt_f(u_iv_j) &=& f(u_i)+f(u_iv_j)+f(v_j) \\
       &=& i+nj+m+i+n+j \\
       &=& 2i+j(1+n)+n+m
    \end{eqnarray*}
 
 
 
 The weights of all the edges are different under the labeling $f$ which means that the labeling $f$ is EAT.\\ \
 \\
 Moreover, for the vertex $u_i\in X_n$, we obtain the vertex weights as follows:
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 \begin{eqnarray*}
 
   wt_f(u_i)& = & f(u_i)+\sum_{j=1}^mf(u_iv_j), \ \ \ 1\leq i\leq n \\
    &=& i+\sum_{j=1}^mnj+m+i  \\
    &=& i(1+m)+\frac{m}{2}(m(n+2)+n) \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ (2.1)
 \end{eqnarray*}
 For the vertex $v_j\in Y_m$, we obtain the vertex-weight
 \begin{eqnarray*}
 
    wt_f(v_j) &=& f(v_j)+\sum_{i=1}^nf(u_iv_j), \ \ \ \ \ 1\leq j\leq m \\
    &=& n+j+\sum_{i=1}^nnj+m+i \\
    &=& j(1+n^2)+\frac{n}{2}(2m+n+3) \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ (2.2)
 \end{eqnarray*}
 
 
 

 The weights of the vertices are distinct under the labeling $f$ which implies that the labeling $f$ is VAT.\\ \
 \\
 Also, from equation (2.1), $wt_f(u_i)<wt_f(u_{i+1})$ whenever $f(u_i)<f(u_{i+1})$ and from equation (2.2), $wt_f(v_j)<wt_f(v_{j+1})$ whenever $f(v_j)<f(v_{j+1})$. This implies that $K_{n,m}$ is a weak ordered graph.\\ \
 \\
 Finally, since the graph $K_{n,m}$ admits the labeling $f$ that is simultaneously EAT and VAT, then $K_{n,m}$ is a TAT graph.\\ \
\\
 Case $2$: $n$ odd and $m$ even.\\
 By interchanging the partition set $X_n$ with $Y_m$ and $Y_m$ with $X_n$ in case $1$ above gives the result.\\ \
\\
 Case $3$: $n,m$ odd.\\
 Consider the labeling $f:K_{n,m}\rightarrow \{1,2,...,p+q\}$ defined as follows:
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex7.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="f(u_{i})=n+m-2i+1,\ \ \ 1\leq i\leq n,\ \ \ m>n" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>u</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>m</mi></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>i</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><mn>   1</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>i</mi><mo>≤</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="17.5pt">,</mo><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>></mo><mi>n</mi></mrow></mrow></math>

text: $$f(v_j)=\left\{\begin{array}{c}{\hspace{1.0cm}}j,\ \ \ 1\leq j\leq m-n\\ n+2j-m,\ \ \ m-n+1\leq j\leq m \end{array}\right.$$

n+2j-m,\ \ \ m-n+1\leq j\leq m\end{array}\right." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>{</mo><mtable displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="center"><mrow><mrow><mpadded lspace="28.5pt" width="+28.5pt"><mi>j</mi></mpadded><mo>,</mo><mn>   1</mn></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mi>j</mi><mo>≤</mo><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="center"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>+</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>j</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>m</mi></mrow><mo rspace="17.5pt">,</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mi>j</mi><mo>≤</mo><mi>m</mi></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable><mi/></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
Since $f$ is a weak ordered, then for $j=1,2,...,n-1$, we have that $wt_f(v_j)\leq wt_f(v_{j+1})$ which follows from Theorem \ref{TM2}.\\ \
\\
By the symbol $u$, we denote the vertex of $K_{n,n}\oplus K_1$ not belonging to $K_{n,n}$.\\ \
\\
We define a new labeling $g$ of $K_{n,n}\oplus K_1$ such that

prevtext:
Since $f$ is a weak ordered, then for $j=1,2,...,n-1$, we have that $wt_f(v_j)\leq wt_f(v_{j+1})$ which follows from Theorem \ref{TM2}.\\ \
\\
By the symbol $u$, we denote the vertex of $K_{n,n}\oplus K_1$ not belonging to $K_{n,n}$.\\ \
\\
We define a new labeling $g$ of $K_{n,n}\oplus K_1$ such that
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex12.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="g(x)=f(x),\ \ \ \ \ \ x\in V(K_{n,n})\cup E(K_{n,n})" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>g</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="32.5pt">,</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>∈</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>V</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>∪</mo><mrow><mi>E</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
It is easy to see that $g$ is a bijection from $V(K_{n,n}\oplus K_1)\cup E(K_{n,n}\oplus K_1)$ to the set $\{1,2,...,2p+q+1\}$.\\ \
\\ For the vertex-weights under labeling $g$, we have the following:
\begin{eqnarray*}

  wt_g(u) &=& g(u)+\sum^n_{i=1}g(u_iu)+\sum^n_{j=1}g(v_ju) \\
   &=& p+q+1+\sum^n_{i=1}p+q+i+1+\sum^n_{j=1}p+q+j+n+1 \\
   &=& (1+p)(p+q+1+n)
\end{eqnarray*}




For vertex $u_i, \ \ \ \i=1,2,...,n$, we have:
\begin{eqnarray*}

  wt_g(u_i) &=& g(u_i)+\sum_{v_j\in N(u_i)}g(u_iv_j)+g(u_iu) \\
   &=& wt_f(u_i)+p+q+i+1 \\
   & \geq & wt_f(u_{i+1})+p+q+i+1 \\
   &> & wt_f(u_{i+1})+p+q+i+2 \\
   &=& wt_g(u_{i+1})
\end{eqnarray*}






Moreover, for $j=1,2,...,n$, we get

\\
We have $wt_f(v_j)$ from Theorem \ref{TM2}, hence we have
\begin{eqnarray*}

  wt_g(v_j) &=& wt_f(v_j)+p+q+n+j+1 \\
   & \leq & wt_f(v_{j+1})+p+q+j+n+1 \\
   &< & wt_f(v_{j+1})+p+q+n+j+2 \\
   &=& wt_g(v_{j+1})
\end{eqnarray*}





Thus the vertex-weights are all different.\\ \
\\

\begin{eqnarray*}

  wt_g(u) &=& g(u)+\sum^n_{i=1}g(u_iu)+\sum^n_{j=1}g(v_ju) \\
   &=& p+q+1+\sum^n_{i=1}p+q+i+1+\sum^n_{j=1}p+q+j+n+1 \\
   &=& (1+p)(p+q+1+n)
\end{eqnarray*}

   &=& wt_g(u_{i+1})
\end{eqnarray*}
